channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: Who is the ‘spy sheikh’ who bought a secret stake in a Trump-linked crypto firm?
Did missiles filled with water and faulty silos lead to China’s military purge?
Who is Laura Fernandez, Costa Rica's tough-talking president-elect?
Trump wanted to attack Iran but is now making a deal. So what changed?
Why are Iranians boycotting makeup and skincare giant Huda Beauty?
What exactly is bhajan clubbing, which has India’s Gen Z in thrall?
Pakistan’s phantom arms boom: How domestic diplomacy is manufacturing a global lie
item.description: When Pakistan cannot deliver economic stability, it starts delivering narratives

item.title: How India and Arab world cement civilisational ties for today’s challenges
item.description: Several geopolitical, economic, and security challenges currently impact the partnership between India and the Arab League nations, but both sides want a 'strategic reset' aimed at transforming traditional ties into a modern, multi-sectoral partnership

item.title: Defence budget surge signals India’s push for capacity building, self-reliance
item.description: The pattern of budgetary allocation is a clear signal that the domestic industrial complex is being prioritised and will be encouraged to ensure Atmanirbharta and build capacity amid growing security challenges

item.title: Beyond tariffs: How Budget 2026 re-engineers export competitiveness amid Trumpian disruptions
item.description: Budget 2026 internalises the logic of making our exports more competitive across the board

item.title: India’s defence budget push signals preference for hard deterrence
item.description: The hike in defence outlay is a recognition that India faces significant challenges to its fundamental sovereignty, and this needs hard power, not mere moral posturing

item.title: UGC episode exposes why Bharat must reclaim its history, decolonise civilisational narrative
item.description: The choice before Bharat is stark: either we reclaim our narrative, or we allow others — foreign as well as domestic — to write it against us. The society may not be as vigilant as it was this time
